sections.summary: The Prophet is commanded to fear Allah and rely on Him while disregarding the instructions of hypocrites and disbelievers. It establishes social laws regarding **adoption** and the practice of **Zihar**, while affirming the spiritual priority of the Messenger over the believers and the solemn **covenant** taken from the prophets.

This range describes the severe trial faced by the believers during the siege of the **Confederates**, where Allah provided support through wind and invisible forces. It contrasts the steadfastness of the faithful with the **hypocrisy** of those who sought excuses to flee, exposing their lack of faith and their fear of death [516–518].

The Prophet is identified as an **excellent example** for those seeking Allah and the Last Day, characterized by his unwavering resolve during battle. The narrative concludes with the defeat of the allied tribes and the judgment upon the **People of the Book** who aided them, granting the believers inheritance of their lands and property.

Allah offers the wives of the Prophet a choice between the worldly life and the **Home of the Hereafter**, mandating high standards of conduct for their unique status. It emphasizes the **purification** of the prophetic household and enumerates the shared spiritual qualities and rewards for both Muslim men and women [518–519].

The text establishes the necessity of **submission** to divine decrees and recounts the Prophet's marriage to the former wife of Zaid to clarify the legality of marrying the ex-spouses of adopted sons. It affirms that Muhammad is not the father of any man among the community but is the Messenger and the **Seal of the Prophets** [519–520].

Believers are exhorted to engage in frequent **remembrance (Dhikr)** of Allah to transition from darkness to light. The Prophet’s mission is defined as a **witness**, herald of good news, warner, and an illuminating beacon for humanity.

Specific ordinances are provided regarding the **waiting period (Iddah)** for divorced women and the distinct marriage regulations assigned to the Prophet. These verses detail the categories of women permitted to him and establish a limit on any further marriages to spare him difficulty [520–521].

This section mandates rules for visiting the Prophet's home, including the requirement to speak to his wives from behind a **screen (Hijab)** to ensure purity of heart. It commands the believers to offer **blessings (Salawat)** upon the Prophet and warns of severe consequences for those who insult or slander the believers [521–522].

Believing women are commanded to draw their **outer garments (Jilbab)** over themselves to be recognized for their modesty and protected from harassment. It issues a stern warning to **hypocrites** and rumormongers in the city, stating they will be cursed and removed if they persist in causing discord.

sections.theme: The Hour and the Divine Trust
sections.summary: The surah concludes by noting that knowledge of the **Hour** belongs to Allah alone and describing the regret of those who followed misguided leaders into the Fire. It calls for **straightforward speech** and recalls how humanity accepted the **Divine Trust (Amanah)** which the heavens and earth were too apprehensive to bear [522–523].
